title: How to determine R1 in the voltage divider circuit - Quora

response.answer_text: Assuming you have two resistors, R1 being the lower and R2 being the upper resistor, here’s how I might do it. And Vin. First determine how much current you want to expend on the divider. It should be at least 100 times any current being drawn off the junction to minimize any distortion of the value. But it can’t be too high… or you’ll waste a lot of power. I’d choose something like I = 1 mA. Now you want Vj the voltage at the junction, developed at R1 with current, so R1 = Vj/I Now its easy, you have a value for R1; Now just solve for (R1+R2) * .001 A = Vin or alternately R2 = (Vin-Vj)/.001 A Now just to make sure go back and calculate P = I^2/R for both resistors and make sure you have high enough wattage resistors by a safety factor of two.
